tasks: Create a list of 10 pain points for a hypothetical product using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework ( reference: https://lawsofux.com/jobs-to-be-done/). Document each point with a brief description and potential solutions. Score improvement: +5% in User Research & Validation category

Conduct 2 user interviews on a topic of your choice, taking detailed notes on the participants' thoughts and feelings (reference: https://nngroup.com/articles/usability-interviews/). Aim to identify at least 3 pain points. Score improvement: +5% in User Research & Validation category

Develop a basic understanding of Jakob's Law by creating a simple wireframe for a website with clear typography and color scheme (reference: https://lawsofux.com/jakobs-law/). Ensure the design is accessible and easy to read. Score improvement: +2% in UX Fundamentals category

Apply the Aesthetic-Usability Effect by designing a simple UI component (e.g., button or form field) with clear typography, color contrast, and sufficient padding. Test your design on 3 users to ensure usability (reference: https://lawsofux.com/aesthetic-usability-effect/). Score improvement: +2% in UX Fundamentals category

Create a basic prototype of a product using Figma or Adobe XD, incorporating the principles of Miller's Law (reference: https://lawsofux.com/millers-law/). Ensure the design is intuitive and easy to use. Score improvement: +3% in UI Craft & Visual Design category

Develop your collaboration skills by participating in a 1-hour online discussion forum on UX topics, actively engaging with others' ideas and providing constructive feedback (reference: https://lawsofux.com/). Score improvement: +2% in Collaboration & Communication category

Develop a more advanced understanding of the 10 Usability Heuristics by creating a case study on how to apply one heuristic (e.g., visibility of system status) to a real-world product. Score improvement: +5% in UX Fundamentals category

Create a wireframe for a complex UI component (e.g., a dashboard or settings panel), applying the principles of Jakob's Law and Aesthetic-Usability Effect. Test your design on 3 users to ensure usability. Score improvement: +4% in UI Craft & Visual Design category
Conduct 2 user interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework, documenting at least 5 pain points and potential solutions. Score improvement: +5% in User Research & Validation category

Create a comprehensive design system for a hypothetical product, incorporating principles from Miller's Law and Jakob's Law. Ensure the design is accessible, intuitive, and visually appealing. Score improvement: +5% in UI Craft & Visual Design category

Develop an advanced understanding of the 10 Usability Heuristics by creating a case study on how to apply multiple heuristics to a real-world product. Score improvement: +5% in UX Fundamentals category

Create a final portfolio piece that showcases your skills in collaboration and communication, including a written explanation of your design decisions and user research findings. Score improvement: +5% in Collaboration & Communication category

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, you have the unique opportunity to shape the user experience of innovative products and services. To excel in this role, focus on developing a strong foundation in UX fundamentals, refining your visual design skills, and honing your research and collaboration abilities through targeted learning and practice.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Applying Occam's Razor in UX Design
topics.summary: Mastering Occam's Razor will help Explorer designers simplify complex design decisions and prioritize user needs.
practice_points: Analyze 3 existing products and identify areas where Occam's Razor could be applied to improve design decisions. Document findings in a written report (approx. 500 words).
Create a simple wireframe of a hypothetical product feature, applying Occam's Razor to prioritize functionality over aesthetics. Justify design choices with evidence from the law.
Conduct an interview with a UX designer who has experience applying Occam's Razor in their work. Ask them to share specific examples and challenges they faced. Document insights and takeaways.

topics.name: Understanding Jakob’s Law for Effective Navigation
topics.summary: Mastering Jakob’s Law will help Explorer designers create intuitive navigation systems that reduce cognitive load.
practice_points: Analyze 3 existing websites and identify areas where Jakob’s Law could be improved. Suggest specific changes to enhance navigation, supported by evidence from the law.
Create a simple wireframe of a hypothetical website feature, applying Jakob’s Law to prioritize clear labeling and concise menus. Justify design choices with reference to the law.
Conduct an experiment testing the effect of label placement on user behavior (e.g., using A/B testing tools). Document findings and discuss implications for design decisions.

topics.name: Integrating Law of Proximity in Visual Design
topics.summary: Applying the Law of Proximity will help Explorer designers create visually appealing and intuitive designs that reduce visual noise.
practice_points: Analyze 3 existing products with effective use of proximity in their design. Identify specific design elements that contribute to this effect and document findings.
Create a simple wireframe of a hypothetical product feature, applying the Law of Proximity to group related elements together. Justify design choices with reference to the law.
Conduct an exercise testing the effect of grouping on user behavior (e.g., using Figma or Adobe XD). Document findings and discuss implications for design decisions.
